results.title: White dust and lies
results.brief_description: A man lies dying in hospital. He is suffering from mesothelioma. His daughter, a trained nurse and filmmaker, searches in the past, present and future to find answers to the unanswered questions about his death. Her search uncovers the legal and moral issues raised by the link between exposure to asbestos and cancer and the ongoing fight for compensation for sufferers of asbestos related disease and government action to raise public awareness of the dangers of asbestos. Narrated by Jacqy Phillips. Produced with assistance from the Asbestos Diseases Foundation of NSW.

results.title: White clay and ochre
results.brief_description: Australian aboriginal cave paintings in ochre tell of their tribal life in western New South Wales. Finger, brush and stencil techniques are used to portray hunting kangaroos and emus, corroborees, magic and ritual maps. Special equipment is used by a field party to copy the paintings to scale for detailed scientific record and research. A cave-floor is carefully excavated to find implements used by the cave dwellers, and charcoal samples taken for dating tests. Music from “Namatjira” by Clive Douglas.

results.title: White Christmas
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Robert Emmett Dolan and Michael Curtiz
results.brief_description: White Christmas is a treasury of Irving Berlin classics, among them “Count Your Blessings Instead of Sheep”, “Sisters”, “Blue Skies”, and the beloved holiday song “White Christmas”. Two talented song-and-dance men (Bing Crosby and Danny Kaye) team up after the war. One winter they join forces with a sister act (Rosemary Clooney and Vera-Ellen) and trek to Vermont for a white Christmas. The result is “the stuff dreams are made of”.

results.title: White blood cells: defense against disease
results.brief_description: Shows how the white blood cells capture the diseased organisms and destroy them. Special cells not only destroy bacteria, but are also capable of removing white blood cells that have been overcome in their battle with the invading organisms. Removal of invading organisms prevents them from multiplying and overwhelming the body defences. Shows the white blood cells in all the various work they do.

results.title: White Australia Policy
results.creator_credit: Student Action of Melbourne University and Unifed Productions
results.brief_description: A documentary record culled from television and other news reports on the White Australia Policy as it found expression in topical incidents in 1961, 1962 and 1963. It is a protest against the White Australia Policy and a record of the events in the history of Student Action. Compiled and edited by Peter Tammer. Dedicated to the memory of Bill Thomas, student leader.

results.title: White-throat
results.brief_description: A nature film without commentary photographed in Canada’s Algonquin Park. A white-throated sparrow is the central character, but other inhabitants are included: young wolves at play, other birds, shoals of fish in a lake, and a beaver at work.

results.title: Whistling Smith
results.creator_credit: ONF | NFB, Barrie Howells, Michael Scott and Marrin Canell
results.brief_description: Sergeant Bernie “Whistling” Smith pounds the beat on Vancouver’s east side - the hang-out of petty criminals, down-and-outs, and a variety of unsavory characters. His policing is unorthodox. To many a drug user, petty thief, or young woman drawn into prostitution, he is more than the iron hand of the law, he is also counsellor and friend. Here is a revealing insight into one side of big-city life and a tough cop with a big heart.

results.title: Whistle for Willie
results.creator_credit: Weston Woods Studios, Morton Schindel and Mal Wittman
results.brief_description: The story of a little boy trying to learn how to whistle for his dog the way the older boys do is told in lovely simple words and beautiful glowing pictures. The minimal animation adds beauty to Ezra Jack Keats’ cut-paper illustrations. Story teller: Jane Harvey. From the book written and illustrated by Ezra Jack Keates.

results.title: Whistle down the wind [study extract]
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Mary Hayley Bell, this extract is the story about a group of children living on a remote farm in the north of England who find a man whom the believe to be Christ. In reality he is a murderer on the run from justice. In the extract we see the children in their country environment and at their home situation. For the first time since “Christ” came to the barn, they talk with him. In the farmhouse, at tea, their father questions Kelly about talking to strange men, which she denies. After leaving the village shop with goods for the man, the three children meet a crowd of friends. The crowd eventually follows them to the farm gate and Kathy is persuaded to let them see “Jesus”.

results.title: Whistle down the wind
results.creator_credit: Beaver Films, Richard Attenborough and Bryan Forbes
results.brief_description: Based on Mary Hayley Bell’s popular novel, this is a charming and thoughtful study of the fragile nature of childhood trusts and beliefs. Hayley Mills and Alan Bates give excellent performances in this story of three innocent children who find a fugitive from the law in their barn and believe that he is Jesus. Produced by award-winning Richard Attenborough, this film is a poignant unveiling of the children’s gradual understanding of the truth, which will delight adults and children alike.
